author: Charles White
title: FlyBe flight from Glasgow to Birmingham disrupted by engine 'failure' | Metro News
text:
Passenger captures moment planes engine stopped forcing emergency landing Charles White Thursday 23 Feb 2017 3:51 pm The moment one of the plane’s engine stopped (Picture: John A. MacInnes/Press Scotland) 
A domestic flight was forced to make an emergency landing after an engine was shut down during Storm Doris. 
The terrifying incident was captured on Twitter by John A MacInnes. Woman stops brutal gang attack by using her car as a weapon 
Flight BE783, operated by FlyBe, was flying from Glasgow to Birmingham when the decision was made to shut down one engine. 
The dramatic emergency was captured by MacInnes who tweeted: ‘Oh shit. Number one engine has failed and we’re returning to Glasgow for an emergency landing!’ 
Adding later that the staff ‘performed as one exceptional team’ and called the pilots ‘amazing.’ The pilots were thought to be former RAF (Picture: John A. MacInnes/Press Scotland) 
The pair were reportedly both former RAF pilots and landed the plane in Glasgow without any further incident. 
Initially it was believed that the flight was disrupted because of a failed engine but FlyBe have confirmed that the pilot deliberate shut one down following a ‘technical fault.’ 
Other flights have been affected by Storm Doris including a KLM jet landing at Leeds Bradford Airport in the morning, when the plan moved from side to side. Woman wants 'catfishing' to be made illegal after man duped her for almost a year 
A Flybe spokesman told Metro.co.uk: ‘Flybe can confirm that the above flight returned to Glasgow airport following a technical fault that resulted in the captain electing to shut down the number one engine as a safety precaution. The pilot followed all required procedures and the aircraft landed safely without incident. 
‘The Bombardier Q400 aircraft is designed to continue flying safely with one of its engines shut down but, as is standard procedure, the aircraft was met by the airport’s emergency service vehicles. All 46 passengers disembarked as normal when the aircraft arrived on stand. 
‘The safety of its passengers and crew is the airline’s number one priority and the airline apologises for any inconvenience experienced.’
